content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Just the fact that I completed the puzzle demonstrates how nice a job the author has done. I struggled with the algebra. I struggled even more with the geometry. The test cases did a great job of keeping me on track. I thoroughly enjoyed the puzzle even while dealing with tremendous frustration. I support the "hard" classification. Great job!

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Already explained.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Here we go again !
And another round :)

Hey CodinGamer! Your contribution has unfortunately not been moderated on time and will temporarily be removed from the system... But no worries! You can republish it anytime to give it another chance! :)
challenging :)
Such a great challenge !

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Already explained, and my problem with new test/validator is fixed.
Very good puzzle.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: The puzzle is well-defined.
The underlying problem of detecting complicated interactions between objects commonly occurs when developing video games.

Inserting tests and validators 4 and 5. 

Validator and test offset positioned after the 2 new tests/validators 4 and 5 (Old Test and Validator 4 has become Test and Validator 6; 5 -> 7; 6 -> 8; 7 -> 9).

Solved in Python.
I thought there would be some precision issues (i.e. "butterfly effect"), but it turned out not be a problem. Just used regular Python floats.
I think this is closer to Medium than Hard difficulty.

Test 4 is a mean step up from Test 3.
It's the first test with a mix of both bird-wall and bird-bird collisions and there are *dozens* of them.
How about a test with just a couple of each?

What does "no movement possible" mean?
That the birds are in collision at the start of the puzzle?
Maybe just don't have cases like that?
Here we go again !

Hey CodinGamer! Your contribution has unfortunately not been moderated on time and will temporarily be removed from the system... But no worries! You can republish it anytime to give it another chance! :)

Looks cool but I'm not going to have time to try it before the period expires.
Resubmit maybe?
It seems very nice, I cannot try before 2 days because your puzzle seems need 1-2 hours to be done, but I will try later if is still needed

Beautiful puzzle! A good story, clear instructions, and enough dimensions to have quite a bit of coding fun. If I find the time I will try to work towards approving, but already I would like to express my upvote.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Roundings problems are fixed, it seems to work with slow languages. The puzzle is nice because you don't need to be a God with mathematics, just think a bit. Good job.
Removal of tests 8, 9 and 10, which seem to contain too many collisions and cause a significant divergence depending on how the puzzle is solved.
Add test/validator 10 where double and long double give the same result
Add test/validator 9 where double and long double give the same result
Change Test 5 to have the same result between double and long double

Solved (in C++ like Sirios).
There are some rounding problems with test 5 (validator 5 is OK), we checked it together with Sirios and we found the corrected results with long double instead of double (need to update some validators). However, I don't want to use long double because I don't know if it works with other languages.

Maybe you should reduce the number of birds collisions to 200 maximum.

I have bigger differences on test/validator 8 but I don't know yet if it's rounding problems or not.

Moreover, it would be nice if someone could solve it in slower languages like python or ruby.

Hello,

My contribution is now on "Ready".

Please, for those who are ready to validate it, please really test the solution without using my code. 

I'd rather have my contribution validated after the time it takes than have it released quickly with problems.

Thanks,
Elimination of constraint: "response time"

Add "at time [[t]]" for input about x, y, vx, vy
Fix constraints for t, n, vx, vy
I hope you received enough feedback from the community to improve your contribution. Once you have made the necessary updates, publish your contribution!
Add test and validator 7 and 8
Change output definition when no movement is possible. Now display "No movement possible!"
Add case with no possible movement "6. No mouvement".

Update [[h]] and [[w]] limits to make sense. The limit is now [0,w] for width instead of [0,w[ and [0,h] for height instead of [0,h[.

Update :
- The size of the aviary is defined by a height ([[h]]) and a width ([[w]]) whose origin is located at [0,0]. The height positions are therefore between 0 and [[h]]-1 and the width positions are between 0 and [[w]]-1.
By :
- The size of the aviary is defined by a height ([[h]]) and a width ([[w]]) whose origin is located at [0,0]. The height positions are therefore between 0 and [[h]] inclusive and the width positions are between 0 and [[w]] inclusive.

Add:
Test and validateur 5.

Add:
The size of the aviary is defined by a height ([[h]]) and a width ([[w]]) whose origin is located at [0,0]. The height positions are therefore between 0 and [[h]]-1 and the width positions are between 0 and [[w]]-1.

Update:
"The [[x]] and [[y]] position of all birds could be determined a time [[t]] after the shot, thanks to the surveillance system, taking into account that the origin of the aviary is at  [0,0]."

By:
"- The [[x]] and [[y]] position of all birds could be determined a time [[t]] after the shot, thanks to the surveillance system."

Update:
"the [[x]] and [[y]] position of all birds could be determined a time [[t]] after the shot, thanks to the surveillance system."

By:
"The [[x]] and [[y]] position of all birds could be determined a time [[t]] after the shot, thanks to the surveillance system, taking into account that the origin of the aviary is at  [0,0]."

Goal
* If it makes a difference when the coordinate system is defined differently, please mention how it works for this puzzle (i.e. where the origin is, and towards which directions x- and y-coordinates increase).

Input
* Line 2, Line 4 and Next n lines: Suggest to change "pigeon(s)" to "bird(s)" for consistency.

* Line 3: Please change "wich" to "which".

* Line 3: Suggest to change "wall" to "an edge of the aviary" (because it isn't necessarily a wall; it may be the ceiling or the floor, I guess?)

* Line 4: Please change "wich" to "which".

Output
* Please change "[[n]] lines with" to "<<[[n]] lines>>:".

* Please change "[[[x]],[[y]]]" to "{{[}}[[x]]{{,}}[[y]]{{]}}".

* Please change "shoot" to "shot".

* Please change "sort" to "sorted".

* Please format "id" (in "sorted by id") as a [[variable]].

Cases
* Please revise the cases so that each pair of test and validator are similar but not the same.

Cover picture
* Suggest to upload a cover picture for the puzzle.

Thanks.

Hi,

That seems like an interesting puzzle but what's the law of reflection? 
You probably need to define it in the statement, I doubt that's considered as common knowledge. Obviously you could find it on Google but I don't think that having to search a formula on Google in order to be able to solve a puzzle should be a thing.
Congratulations for your first contrib, I'll try to solve it ;)

Hello,

It's not quite finished yet, but I'm putting it at your disposal for any advice you may have or so that you can try it out.

If you could also confirm that my algo is correct, that would be great.

I welcome any comments.

Hello Remi,

Thanks,

Ok, I'm really interested to know if there are any rounding problems. Let me know :).

Hi cedricdd,

Okay, good point. 

I just added it. Do you think it's enough?

Hello 5DN1L,

Thanks for all your suggestions.

I've just applied most of them (except for "Goal" and "Cases".

For "Goal", it doesn't really matter. Everyone is free to represent their aviary as they wish, since I don't ask them to draw it. It doesn't change the output values. Do you think it's necessary to indicate one arbitrarily?

The test cases differ from the validator cases, and additional cases may be on the way.

Thanks
Small typo: mouvement -> movement (in the test name)
Thank you for breaking in the ground :p
Thanks :).

Thanks @GlaceCoding,

I'll put it back in 2 days.
Yes of course :)

Hello LeifTerry,

Thanks for the test!

Yes, this means that no birds could have moved even if time was tending towards infinity.

I thought it would be interesting to add this test to have an algorithm that began to take certain limitations into account.

What an idea! 

I'll think about it, thanks for the suggestion.

Well done!

I did have accuracy problems on the first data sets, but with Remi's algo, my C++ code and my python code I came up with sets that gave the same result. I'm glad you're getting the same results too.

Ok for your evaluation of the difficulty to medium. That gives us 2 opinions in hard and 1 in medium. I'll change it if other people think it's medium too.

Thanks for the tests in any case.

New problems for me, in C and in C++, with new test 5 and new validator 5. Don't know yet if it is a rounding problem or other.
Is there a particular trap with those tests ?

Hello Remi,

The new test (and validator) 5 starts with birds in direct contact right from the start.

LeifTerry pointed out that the "No movement possible!" was detectable by checking that the birds were in contact from the start, so I added this test.
Ok ... my solution doesn't print "Mo mvt" but bad answers (for all birds), I have to check what happens with the initial collision.

I found my problem. I wasn't considering that the collision could happen at t0, because I would have seen it at previous computation. I forgot that it could happen at t=0 before the first computation.
I solved my problem by changing a '>' by '>=' on a double ^^
Add Test and Validator 4 with just a couple of each.

I can't figure out a case where the birds can't move.
Except for pathological cases with v=0 or birds off the map or birds interpenetrating.
Can't the birds always move?

In test (and validator) 6 the birds are completely constrained between the walls and neighboring birds, so it's not possible for a single bird to move even if time were infinite.

According to the puzzle hypothesis, the birds change direction infinitely, but don't move a hair.

Oh, ok.
I don't think that needs to be a special case, but hey, it's your puzzle.
You probably want to change some of your test cases and add the following:
* two birds touching at start but moving away
* two birds touching at start but moving towards

My code passed with only the logic: if two birds touching at start then print "No movement possible".

Hmmm, ok.

As soon as I have a bit of time, I'll have a look. I hope to look at it this week, otherwise it should be next weekend.

Thanks for the tests and suggestions!
Add Test and Validator 5 with contact at the beginning.

Yes ... of corsa !
(f*cking television)
Hello @GlaceCoding, I'm writing to see if you're still interested in testing my contribution. I'd be delighted to have your comments and vote as this one is having trouble getting validated :).
Sorry my schedule was crazy (full) at work
Hello @jddingemanse, I'm writing to see if you're still interested in testing my contribution. I'd be delighted to have your comments and vote as this one is having trouble getting validated :).

Well I started but got stuck (and didn't have the time to pursue it more deeply). I think in the meantime you have added some tests/validators that might help me get further (shorter cases for the more complex dynamics before the long cases come). If I manage to find the time I'll try to get your contribution validated this turn around.
Thanks!

Hello Rafarafa,

Fixed!

Thanks

Thank you for your reply and the changes.

Regarding the coordinate system thing, I wasn't sure about it. That's why I asked.

Comments on the updated version:

(birds/pigeons: It seems you've misunderstood my previous comment, so I'll be clearer below.)

Input
* Line 2: Please change "bird(s)" to "bird".

* Line 4: Please change "pigeons" to "birds".

* Next n lines: Please change "pigeon" to "bird" (3 times).

Output
* Please delete the quotation marks.

Cases
* I still see the test cases being the same as the validators. For example, both Test 1 and Validator 1 have the following input:
100 100
20
1
2
1 1 1 -1 -2
2 4 24 -1 -3

Thanks again.

Hello 5DN1L,

Thanks for your second feedback.

I had indeed misunderstood the renaming of pigeon to bird. I only did it in one place. Normally there should be none left (except in my source code).

I've updated the validators. I'll probably create more cases soon.

Thanks.
Finally you're right, it makes sense to mention the origin of the aviary. I've adapted the description. Thank you.

Thanks, but it doesn't really say much about the position, does it. Origin = (0, 0), but where? I've created an example for your reference:
https://imgur.com/a/iQBZKrR
Ok, I understand. I've changed it. Thanks.

New comments based on the latest version:

Input
* Suggest to add the words "at time [[t]]" at the end of the last two lines (i.e. descriptions of x, y, vx and vy) for clarity.

Constraints
* Test 5, Validator 5, Test 8 and Validator 8 violate the constraint on n.

* Test 6, Validator 6, Test 7 and Validator 7 violate the constraint on t.

* Please change 0 to -5 for the constraints of vx and vy.

* I don't think you have any control over the response time, so I suggest to delete the last constraint.

Thanks.

Hello,

Thank you for this last feedback.

Normally, if I'm not mistaken, I've just implemented your proposals, except for the response time, where I'd like your confirmation.

Here I measured the response time by measuring it 10 times via the test in the IDE. According to my measurements, it seems to be concentrated around 300 ms. Does this seem insufficient to you to indicate it in the constraints?

Thank you for your constructive feedback

Thank you for your follow-up and your reply.

Response time issue
* I don't recall any classic puzzle where response time is mentioned in the statement.

* I'm not sure whether response time is the same for all programming languages offered on the CG platform. So the number you've stated may not be necessarily applicable for all.

* Even if response time is the same for all programming languages, it's at CG's discretion to change it, not at yours. You can control the response time only if you use the CodinGame SDK to create a viewer-enabled puzzle/bot game.
Ok, got it. I removed.

Maybe you could also add a link to the wiki, having a visual representation makes it a lot easier to understand.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reflection_(physics)#Laws_of_reflection

Ok,

Done,

Thanks,
